921850.name: Spiderman Cast Covers
921850.sizes_available: One size with instructions for adjusting
921850.notes_html:
The inspiration for these cast covers is my little grandbaby! He was born with Spina Bifida. A little bit about …it’s a neural tube defect that affects approximately 1 in 1000 babies. Somewhere along the line (around 4 weeks in the womb), the skin fails to close along the spinal column and it the spinal cord, along with all the nerves begin pooling in a thin membrane and grow on the outside of the body (sounds more horrible than it actually is, I assure you!)

What normally happens after birth, is a surgery is performed to tuck everything back inside, and close the hole (that’s the simple part). The hard part is it causes paralysis, bowel, bladder, and other hurdles, like hydrocephalus, where brain fluid pools in the ventricles of the brain. Long story short - Lil S has it all! He had a shunt placed 3 days after he was born. To date, he has endured 4 surgeries and the lil guy is only 3.5 years old.

You can find this pattern free on my blog and read more of his story here: Stardust Gold Crochet

Thanks for stopping by,
Much Love,
Tasha

What normally happens after birth, is a surgery is performed to tuck everything back inside, and close the hole (that's the simple part).  The hard part is it causes paralysis, bowel, bladder, and other hurdles, like hydrocephalus, where brain fluid pools in the ventricles of the brain.  Long story short - Lil S has it all!  He had a shunt placed 3 days after he was born.  To date, he has endured 4 surgeries and the lil guy is only 3.5 years old.  

**You can find this pattern free on my blog and read more of his story here:**  [Stardust Gold Crochet][2] 



Thanks for stopping by, 
Much Love,
Tasha

  [1]: https://www.spinabifidaassociation.org/
  [2]: https://www.stardustgoldcrochet.com

users.about_me:
Hi everyone!

I am a crochet designer, skater, and lover of life.  My blog is [Stardust Gold Crochet][1], and I recently opened a shop, go check it out!

**Show me your work!**

#stardustgoldcrochet

**Need pattern support?**

I have a Facebook Group called [Stardust Gold Crochet & Friends][2] where you can ask questions about crochet, share your patterns, and just hang out!

**About me:**

I gather inspiration for my designs from my love of retro, rainbows, classic, modern, boho, and more.  I have very eclectic tastes and whatever inspires I go with!

I hope you enjoy them and thank you for your support in my crochet design journey.

Thank you all for your beautiful patterns and inspiration.


  [1]: https://www.stardustgoldcrochet.com
  [2]: https://www.facebook.com/groups/stardustgoldcrochet

930440.gauge_pattern: (sc in first st, dc in next st) repeat to end of row
930440.name: Catheter Leg Bag Covers
930440.gauge_description: 14 stitches and 11 rows = 4 inches in (sc in first st, dc in next st) repeat to end of row
930440.notes_html:
This pattern was created after a friend requested leg bag covers so she can wear shorts this summer. I had no idea how I was going to do it, but I ordered a pack of leg bags and got to work! I’m keeping these low priced so as many people as possible who need these, or want to make them for charity, are able to!

I used Premier Home Cotton because of the availability of lots of different colors and because it’s mostly cotton, which is important for hygiene. To me this yarn seems slightly thinner than other worsted/aran cotton yarn, but I’m sure any cotton and/or bamboo yarn of this weight will work with this pattern.

pattern_author.name: Becky Tharp
pattern_author.notes:
I’m 32 and dealing with some health problems that are very disabling. At age 25 I needed a new hobby that I could do sitting down or even in bed. My mom had taught me the basics of crocheting when I was 12, so I decided to try it again and see if it was something I liked. Not only do I like it, but I love it! I loved learning all of the different stitches and discovering all of the different things that can be crocheted. Now there are not many crochet techniques that I haven’t tried (and mastered), and I’m beginning to write my own patterns. I especially love making things that are useful as well as decorative. As I write more patterns, I hope to focus mostly on things with a musical theme and disability-related items. 

I’m also a classically trained musician (hence the username). I teach private piano and woodwind lessons and spend a lot of time playing various instruments. I love to read, learn new things, listen to music, go shopping, hang out with friends, and spend time with my two birds, Teddy the caique and Charlie the budgie. I used to spend a lot of my time outdoors doing things like hiking, biking, archery, cross country skiing, ice skating, and anything else that looked like fun. I may not be able to do those things anymore, but I’m still always up for an adventure!

961916.name: Knitted Port Pillow
961916.notes_html:
Port-a-Cath or Catheter Port pillow to protect medical ports from seatbelts. Size is recommended by the Levine Cancer Institute. My husband has been using a sewn version for some time and it’s very welcome, especially after infusions.

Pillow is knitted flat, ties are added during knitting using e-cast on and basic cast off. Then item is folded in half, sides are sewn, piece is stuffed with poly-fill on open side, then pillow is sewn shut.

Sizing allows pillow to be easily tied onto a seatbelt and positioned.

Could be easily adapted to knit in the round.

Items needed:

  • Worsted weight yarn (likely not a full skien)
  • Knitting needles
  • Tapestry needle
  • Poly-fill (a good handful)

Link to pattern at Charlotte Yarn website

969935.name: Half Socks for Orthopedic Boot or Cast
969935.notes_html:
This pattern is intended for use with an orthopedic boot or fiberglass cast to keep the patient’s toes warm during their recovery. The half sock measures about 5 inches in length with a ribbed edge to keep the sock from sliding down.

This pattern was written for an adult woman’s medium shoe size but could be easily adapted to fit any size.

Yarn: Premier Yarns Wool Free Sock yarn but has since been discontinued. Any Light Fingering yarn will work perfectly. About 25 grams (117.5 yards | 107.4 meters) for one half sock.

Needles: US size 1 (2.25 mm) DPNS

Notions: Stitch Markers and some well wishes for your hurt friend.
969935.notes:
This pattern is intended for use with an orthopedic boot or fiberglass cast to keep the patient's toes warm during their recovery. The half sock measures about 5 inches in length with a ribbed edge to keep the sock from sliding down. 

This pattern was written for an adult woman's medium shoe size but could be easily adapted to fit any size. 

**Yarn:**  Premier Yarns Wool Free Sock yarn but has since been discontinued. Any *Light Fingering* yarn will work perfectly. About 25 grams (117.5 yards **|** 107.4 meters) for *one* half sock. 

**Needles:** US size 1 (2.25 mm) DPNS

**Notions:** Stitch Markers and some well wishes for your hurt friend.

packs.yarn_name: Premier Yarns Wool Free Sock Stripes

users.about_me: I taught myself how to knit when I was eighteen. At first I had no clue how to bind off, so I just kept knitting until I had several 10 foot long scarves. When I'd been knitting and binding off for a couple months, I decided the most logical thing to do would be to secretly yarn bomb my entire town at 3AM. Since then, I've become a knit-a-holic. When I learned how to crochet, I decided to jump into the deep end of crocheting by designing my own sweater before I'd even made a granny square. It all worked out! When I'm not knitting or crocheting, I'm part owner of an art studio and a full time chef. I love playing musical instruments, creating any form of art, reading sci-fi and fantasy, traveling, and rock climbing.

973821.name: Crochet Modesty Pouch for Medical Devices
973821.gauge_description: 17 stitches and 9.5 rows = 4 inches in Single crochet
973821.notes_html:
Intended Use
The finished item is designed to hang from an IV stand/hook or from another similar stand, walker, wheelchair, etc for catheter or other type medical device bags for the purpose of concealing what is contained within the bag. The pouch should be created using yarn that is machine-washable for sanitary purposes and long-term use. When created with a quality cotton yarn and washed per the instructions on the yarn label it will endure many washings. These pouches have been donated to our local Veterans Administration Medical Center’s Community Living Center yet there may be other charitable organizations that would be also be appreciative of them.

Materials
Two 4 oz skeins of cotton or cotton/polyester blend yarn
(Recommendation: Lily Sugar n Cream Cotton Yarn)
US Size H/8 (5mm) crochet hook
Yarn needle
Stitch marker or scrap yarn (optional)
Regular needle & thread for hand-sewing (optional)

Specifications
Gauge: 4”x4” square = 17 stitches & 9.5 rows in single crochet Finished Size: 8.5” W x 12.5” L

977705.name: Joey's Toe Cozy
977705.notes_html: My 18 year old son has found himself in a medical boot as the weather has turned chilly. He was frequently complaining that his toes were cold, so I sat down and made him a toe cozy that he can wear by loosening the bottom part of his boot and sliding it on. The boot itself helps to hold the toe cozy on. Even though the yarn calls for 4.5mm needles, I used 3.5mm needles to make the finished piece denser, and hopefully warmer.

978400.gauge_description: 28 stitches and 38 rows = 4 inches in Stockinette Stitch
978400.notes_html: Perfect for a broken finger! Knit a stretchy sock for an individual finger. Fits snugly over bandaging without added pressure to the break. Length is customizable.

users.about_me:
I have been obsessed with crafting since before I could walk. My Mom and Grandma used to graciously give me supplies, which I would turn into my masterpieces. Over the years, I have experimented with all types of mediums, though I always seem to come back to fiber arts.
I've designed patterns for years, but they were written in my version of shorthand that only I could follow. Now I am updating those patterns and writing new ones to share my love of knitting and crochet with other crafters.
Come check out my blog to see all my creative tutorials and patterns.

I’ve designed patterns for years, but they were written in my version of shorthand that only I could follow. Now I am updating those patterns and writing new ones to share my love of knitting and crochet with other crafters.
Come check out my blog to see all my creative tutorials and patterns.

993132.name: Cabled Freestyle Libre Reader Case
993132.notes_html:
Since I am now using the Abbot Freestyle Libre Sensors to collect glucose readings, I wanted a case to carry the Freestyle Libre Reader around in to protect the touchscreen from being scratched up in my purse. I was not very satisfied with the cases available to purchase. Either they did not actually protect the touch screen, leaving it uncovered, or they were unattractive and very expensive - pretty much the cost of the reader itself! I knew there was a better solution!

In this case, the cables provide some nice padding to protect the touch screen from scratches while jangling in my lunch bag or in my purse. The increases on the bottom accommodate the shape of the reader nicely. As the yarn is worsted weight, the sides are also protected from drops to some degree.

This pattern is best suited to someone comfortable with using Judy’s Magic Cast On for toe-up socks, and with cabling.

users.fave_colors: Autumn colours: rust, orange, reds, greys, greens, gold.
users.about_me:
My wonderful grandmother who lived with us taught me to knit around the same time that she moved in, I think, when I was about five. I did everything crafty I could get my hands on as a child, but was most taken with cross stitch with knitting being very much a sideline. I do remember knitting a three colour stranded  colourwork potholder in my youth which was a very high skill level. It might have even been double knitted if my memory serves me well!

I knitted very sparsely in my twenties but took it up again when my kids were old enough that I was constantly carting them around to activities where I then had to sit and wait. Unlike cross stitch, knitting is wondrously portable. Now I literally never leave home without it!  I am pretty much always wearing hand knitted socks to baby my sensitive feet, and I have happily discovered that shawls are the ultimate accessory for those of us with wonky internal temperature regulation systems :wink: .

I will knit for my kids and family upon request if an item is truly wanted, but if I am randomly asked to make something to give away, I am very unlikely to respond positively. The devaluing of needlecrafts is very much linked to the general devaluing of women's labour. If your request demonstates how little you understand the cost, materials, expertise, and time invested in a handmade object I am very unlikely to support your ignorance with a gift. I will, however, patiently teach you how to enjoy this wonderful craft and help you along the way as much as I can if you wish to invest the time to learn.

I knitted very sparsely in my twenties but took it up again when my kids were old enough that I was constantly carting them around to activities where I then had to sit and wait. I am pretty much always wearing hand knitted socks to baby my sensitive feet, and I have happily discovered that shawls are the ultimate accessory for those of us with wonky internal temperature regulation systems .

I will knit for my kids and family upon request if an item is truly wanted, but if I am randomly asked to make something to give away, I am very unlikely to respond positively. The devaluing of needlecrafts is very much linked to the general devaluing of women’s labour. If your request demonstates how little you understand the cost, materials, expertise, and time invested in a handmade object I am very unlikely to support your ignorance with a gift. I will, however, patiently teach you how to enjoy this wonderful craft and help you along the way as much as I can if you wish to invest the time to learn.

1020455.name: Care Workers Special Headband
1020455.gauge_description: 22 stitches and 28 rows = 4 inches in stocking stitch
1020455.notes_html:
Knitting Pattern for a care workers headband with buttons for face masks to attach to.

The headband is fully adjustable, with large buttons for a care worker to attach the straps of their mask over the buttons instead of their ears to make them more comfortable. The large buttons are a tight fit through the buttonholes so that once the headband has been washed and worn a few times, the buttons aren’t going to pop out easily. It is knitted in two pieces, so that the second button can be moved into the correct place so it is level with the other ear so that the mask is kept straight. Its not the prettiest headband in the world, but hopefully it will be comfortable and very practical at the same time, so it saves our very dedicated care workers ears from getting sore.

You will need:

20g dk yarn with a tension of 22sts and 30 rows to 10cm square over stocking stitch, 2 large buttons, 1 x pr 4mm needles. One size fits all.

users.about_me:
Hi, my name is Lynne and I am the person behind DollieBabies. I specialise in my own brand of designer knitting patterns for premature to 3 month old babies or reborn dolls. I've also just written my very first crochet pattern!

I am a single stay at home mum, doing what I love to do...knitting. I have set up a small business selling my knitwear and patterns.

1020891.name: Sore Ear Savers
1020891.notes_html:
Help essential workers with this Sore Ear Saver (SES)! Mask elastics connect to the SES behind the head, allowing a worker’s tired ears a reprieve. Pattern includes instruction for CROCHET, KNIT, AND SEWN.

Materials needed for all versions:
-sewing needle
-thread
-2 buttons (between 15mm-22mm)

Materials needed for crochet/knit version:
-4 weight (worsted) yarn
-4.5mm hook or 4mm needles

Materials needed for sewn version:
-100% cotton fabric

If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me at cuddlycrochetcreatons@gmail.com or on my business page at www.facebook.com/cuddlycrochetcreations

pattern_author.name: Prismatic Fiber and Artistry
pattern_author.notes:
Thank you for your interest in my shop! Though I have been crocheting for more than 20 years, it wasn't until 2018 that I decided to open up my own shop. After doing well for a year, I took the plunge into designing my own patterns.

*If you like my work, please consider following me on my Facebook page! You will be updated when I post finished products or my latest patterns!*

All my patterns are extensively tested. If you find an error or anything confusing, please feel free to reach out to me at prismaticfaa@gmail.com or message me on my Facebook business page.

1021317.name: Add A Little Beauty Mask Holder
1021317.notes_html:
Just because things are crazy and ugly right now, does not mean we can’t create something beautiful from it.

If you are needing to wear a mask and do not like the elastic on your ears, here is a quick and easy pattern to make a holder to attach your mask to. This pattern includes instructions for both a regular and ponytail mask mate.

It only takes 13 yards of yarn and 2 buttons, so a great way to use up your stash.

All of my patterns are written in standard US terms.

Chatty Patty Promotions:

  • Buy more, save more…Add 2 patterns to your cart to receive 10% off of your purchase. Add 4 patterns to your cart and receive 15% off your total purchase!
  • Get a free single pattern of your choice with every $15 spent. eBooks will count towards your $15, but cannot be chosen for your free pattern. Previous purchases made while logged into Ravelry will count towards your $15 too!

Due to Ravlery limitations only one coupon can be used per transaction.

Please note you are purchasing a digital copy of my pattern and due to the nature of digital files there will be no refunds or exchanges. However, I do offer customer support. If you have any problems with the pattern please do not hesitate to contact me, I will gladly do my best to help you through it.

1021684.name: Face Mask Ear Guard
1021684.gauge_description: 12 stitches and 8 rows = 4 inches in dc
1021684.notes_html:
Help support our nurses and doctors!

This pattern is very basic and perfect for those new to crochet. It has two stitches: ch and dc. Links to instructional dc videos are included in the pattern. Photos also provide guidance. Any yarn or hook can be used. I give guidance on how to adjust for gauge differences.

This pattern is free with the hopes that you will donate your creations to those who need it!

Approximate dimensions: 5 x 1 1/2 inches

Medium weight yarn: less than an oz

Skill level: Beginner
Standard US terms used: ch, dc

Materials used: Lily Sugar’n Cream yarn; US H/5.00mm crochet hook; tapestry needle; thread; two buttons; needle

Thank you for stopping by and check back soon for new patterns.
All pictures and patterns copyright to CocoaBe Designs ©

pattern_author.name: Chelsey CocoaBe
pattern_author.notes:
Hello! CocoaBe started with a dream of mine three years ago. I love crochet and the creative outlet it gives me. My mom taught it to me when I was seven years old. I found a blanket in her pattern book and wanted to try it so badly! It had two rows and at the time that seemed so daunting and the process so time-consuming. But she helped me get started and showed me the basics. She completed one row, then I raced to finish the next row. Back and forth we went until we had a beautiful afghan for my bedroom. I still have it! :) And the pattern! 

I hope my patterns will inspire you for years to come and be cherished with your family as well. My design aesthetic is to create modern and simple designs with cozy-textured feels. It is truly my goal to create patterns that inspire love, joy, and cozy-feels (not frustration and despair!) <3 Happy Crochet! 

Thank you for stopping by and check back soon for new patterns. Follow me on instagram to see what I am up to! 

https://www.instagram.com/cocoabedesigns/ All pictures and patterns copyright to CocoaBe ©

1022063.name: Knitted Mask Mate
1022063.notes_html: This is a knitted face mask mate, used to hold the elastics of face masks instead of wearing the elastic on the ears to prevent ears from becoming sore from extended use. I’ve seen several crochet patterns but no knitted ones yet, so I decided I’d give it a go.
1022063.notes: This is a knitted face mask mate, used to hold the elastics of face masks instead of wearing the elastic on the ears to prevent ears from becoming sore from extended use. I've seen several crochet patterns but no knitted ones yet, so I decided I'd give it a go.

users.about_me:
![image title][1] It's been a while since I updated this! Raveler #805575 Hi, I'm Rachel. I'm a wife to Jerek (W.A. 10-26-2010) and mom to a beautiful little girl named Tiri (B.D. 9-5-2011) and a sweet baby boy who was born silent on Dec. 10, 2013, who we named Freddy. On a very happy day in May 2015 we got our rainbow baby, a little guy named Fritz. In March 2017, Fritzy became a big brother when Antoinette joined us. And Antoinette became big sister to Daphne on June 21, 2018. Daphne in turn became a big sister on 9-27-2021 to Benedict. I knit and crochet mostly, but I know how to do lots of other things. Mostly it's just a matter of space. I miss sewing. I am mainly a charity crafter. I love to help people. I have this skill, and I feel I should use it to benefit others. Of course, I still make things for family! Tiri has a very nice collection of hats, and Freddy was buried in a hat, booties, and sleep sack I had knitted for him. (He is also wearing pajamas.) [Amazon wishlist][2] Thank you for looking. Paypal: nefretirismommy@gmail.com ![image title][3] ![image title][4] ![image title][5] ![image title][6] ![image title][7] ![image title][8] ![39254737375_c6cd6884c4.jpg][9] ![Out][10] ![image title][11] **Following is a place to keep this for now:** "Mayo Clinic Hospital - Methodist Campus Volunteers KNITTING PATTERNS BABY CAPS Materials: Use baby yarn as supplied by the Volunteer Office Needles: 1 pair size 6. (If a loose knitter, use size 5.) **if you are using the Red Heart Soft Baby yarn, please use a size 4 needle. Directions: Style I Cast on 72 stitches. Work in K2 P2 ribbing for 4 inches. (The 4 inches is very important. Please measure!) For the cap body, work in stockinet as follows: K one row, P one row for a total of 14 rows. (Must be 14 rows!) Decrease: (on right side) Row 1 *K4, slip 1, K1, PSSO* (Pass slipped stitch over) and repeat across row. Row 2 Purl across. Row 3 K3, slip 1, K1, PSSO; repeat across. Row 4 Purl across. Row 5 K2, slip 1, K1, PSSO; repeat across. Row 6 Purl across. Row 7 K1, slip 1, K1, PSSO; repeat across. Row 8 Purl across. Row 9 K2 together across. Cut yarn leaving a 10-inch length. With needle, pass through all stitches left on the knitting needles. Pull tight; use remaining yarn to sew up the side. A pompom may be attached to the crown; however, this is optional. When gently stretched, bottom ribbing (should not stretch beyond 7 inches) Please note? TOE COZY Materials: 4 ply yarn #7 and 9 needles. Knitted loosely. (Stretch is important!) Cast on 48 stitches on #9 needles. K2, P2 ribbing for 20 rows. Change to #7 needles and knit all stitches and rows for 4 inches. Bind off. Sew up seam on side and across non-ribbed end. This makes a straight bottom to the cozy with NO DECREASES. Crochet a cord on #6 hook – 30 inches long. Thread this through one half of the ribbing. This is to tie around the ankle. If knitting in the round, use three-needle bind off, Kitchener stitch, or the technique of your choice to close the non-ribbed end after knitting for four inches. This pattern without decreases at the toe has been adopted as our official pattern at the request of the departments dispensing the cozies. HAND COZY – METHODIST CAMPUS PATTERN This is knitted in the round with a 16 inch circular needle, size 6 to 8, depending on how tightly you knit, and a set of double-pointed needles. Feel free to drop down a size because you will be continuing to decrease with these. Use four-ply yarn for these and add stripes if you wish. K = Knit P = Purl SKP = Slip one stitch; knit the next; pass slipped stitch over the knit stitch. This will be a decrease. Directions: Cast on 48 stitches and join being careful not to twist the stitches. Insert a marker at the join. K 1, P 1 for 10 rows. This makes the ribbing. Knit for 5 more inches; then begin to decrease as follows, switching to the double pointed needles when necessary: Row 1: *K 6, SKP.* Repeat * to * around row. 42 stitches remain. Row 2: Knit all stitches. Row 3: *K5, SKP.* Repeat * to * around row. 36 stitches remain. Row 4: Knit all stitches. Row 5: *K4, SKP.* Repeat * to * around row. 30 stitches remain. Row 6: Knit all stitches. Row 7: *K4, SKP.* Repeat * to * around row. 24 stitches remain. Row 8: Knit all stitches. Row 9: *K3, SKP.* Repeat * to * around row. 18 stitches remain. Row 10: Knit all stitches. Row 11: SKP across. 9 stitches remain. Cut yarn leaving a 10 inch tail and weave in remaining stitches. Weave in starting tail." [1]:

Anniversary Tickers
[1]: http://

Anniversary Tickers
[1]:

Anniversary Tickers
[1]: https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/736x/6e/c9/05/6ec90502b835c78c74efb15ba3a67c11.jpg [2]: https://www.amazon.com/hz/wishlist/ls/3BG1PTZOCM4IL?ref_=wl_share [3]: https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/-b99_yR6F1e0/UvMMv3AThMI/AAAAAAABqA8/VvC2YR6o3Uk/s350/medal-2014-SWEATERBOARD.jpg [4]: https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/-I5lrOd3A0rc/UvMMr9mDleI/AAAAAAABqAM/tg_CaOWsOfk/s350/medal-2014-HALFPIPE.jpg [5]: https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/-su5K4OKN1tc/UvMM5JPcutI/AAAAAAABqDE/jrWPDWIS1xE/s350/medal-2014-NORDIC.jpg [6]: https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/-JmzZcl3uOVo/UvMMwynK5rI/AAAAAAABqBM/KFDUtcqoL7c/s350/medal-2014-WIPS.jpg [7]: http://www.ravelry.com/forum-images/Bobicus/x78o-xj93st [8]: https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-x6U6-1Y1SsA/UvMMy0-Yn-I/AAAAAAABqBs/vY4JxFDyMHg/s350/medal-2014-CHARITY.jpg [9]: /forum-images/Rachel1989/2yr4u-p899mr [10]: /forum-images/Rachel1989/2yr4w-o2wiup [11]: http://media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/736x/40/aa/55/40aa55635818ba8ad6f730a5b2c650b3.jpg
users.about_me_html:
It’s been a while since I updated this!

Raveler #805575

Hi, I’m Rachel. I’m a wife to Jerek (W.A. 10-26-2010) and mom to a beautiful little girl named Tiri (B.D. 9-5-2011) and a sweet baby boy who was born silent on Dec. 10, 2013, who we named Freddy. On a very happy day in May 2015 we got our rainbow baby, a little guy named Fritz. In March 2017, Fritzy became a big brother when Antoinette joined us. And Antoinette became big sister to Daphne on June 21, 2018. Daphne in turn became a big sister on 9-27-2021 to Benedict.

I knit and crochet mostly, but I know how to do lots of other things. Mostly it’s just a matter of space. I miss sewing.

I am mainly a charity crafter. I love to help people. I have this skill, and I feel I should use it to benefit others. Of course, I still make things for family! Tiri has a very nice collection of hats, and Freddy was buried in a hat, booties, and sleep sack I had knitted for him. (He is also wearing pajamas.)

Amazon wishlist Thank you for looking.

Paypal: nefretirismommy@gmail.com

Following is a place to keep this for now:
“Mayo Clinic Hospital - Methodist Campus Volunteers
KNITTING PATTERNS

BABY CAPS

Materials:
Use baby yarn as supplied by the Volunteer Office

Needles:
1 pair size 6. (If a loose knitter, use size 5.)
if you are using the Red Heart Soft Baby yarn, please use a size 4 needle.
Directions:

Style I
Cast on 72 stitches. Work in K2 P2 ribbing for 4 inches. (The 4 inches is very important. Please measure!) For the cap body, work in stockinet as follows:
K one row, P one row for a total of 14 rows.
(Must be 14 rows!)
Decrease: (on right side)

Row 1
K4, slip 1, K1, PSSO (Pass slipped stitch over) and repeat across row.

Row 2
Purl across.

Row 3
K3, slip 1, K1, PSSO; repeat across.

Row 4
Purl across.

Row 5
K2, slip 1, K1, PSSO; repeat across.

Row 6
Purl across.

Row 7
K1, slip 1, K1, PSSO; repeat across.

Row 8
Purl across.

Row 9
K2 together across.

Cut yarn leaving a 10-inch length. With needle, pass through all stitches left on the knitting needles. Pull tight; use remaining yarn to sew up the side. A pompom may be attached to the crown; however, this is optional.

When gently stretched, bottom ribbing (should not stretch beyond 7 inches)
Please note?
TOE COZY

Materials:
4 ply yarn #7 and 9 needles. Knitted loosely. (Stretch is important!)
Cast on 48 stitches on #9 needles. K2, P2 ribbing for 20 rows. Change to #7 needles and knit all stitches and rows for 4 inches. Bind off. Sew up seam on side and across non-ribbed end. This makes a straight bottom to the cozy with NO DECREASES. Crochet a cord on #6 hook – 30 inches long. Thread this through one half of the ribbing. This is to tie around the ankle.

If knitting in the round, use three-needle bind off, Kitchener stitch, or the technique of your choice to close the non-ribbed end after knitting for four inches.

This pattern without decreases at the toe has been adopted as our official pattern at the request of the departments dispensing the cozies.

HAND COZY – METHODIST CAMPUS PATTERN

This is knitted in the round with a 16 inch circular needle, size 6 to 8, depending on how tightly you knit, and a set of double-pointed needles. Feel free to drop down a size because you will be continuing to decrease with these.
Use four-ply yarn for these and add stripes if you wish.

K = Knit
P = Purl
SKP = Slip one stitch; knit the next; pass slipped stitch over the knit stitch. This will be a decrease.

Directions: Cast on 48 stitches and join being careful not to twist the stitches. Insert a marker at the join. K 1, P 1 for 10 rows. This makes the ribbing.

Knit for 5 more inches; then begin to decrease as follows, switching to the double pointed needles when necessary:

Row 1: K 6, SKP. Repeat * to * around row. 42 stitches remain.
Row 2: Knit all stitches.
Row 3: K5, SKP. Repeat * to * around row. 36 stitches remain.
Row 4: Knit all stitches.
Row 5: K4, SKP. Repeat * to * around row. 30 stitches remain.
Row 6: Knit all stitches.
Row 7: K4, SKP. Repeat * to * around row. 24 stitches remain.
Row 8: Knit all stitches.
Row 9: K3, SKP. Repeat * to * around row. 18 stitches remain.
Row 10: Knit all stitches.
Row 11: SKP across. 9 stitches remain.
Cut yarn leaving a 10 inch tail and weave in remaining stitches. Weave in starting tail.“

1022231.name: Medic Ear Mates
1022231.notes_html:
A quick and simple knit to help protect the ears of our frontline workers during the long hours that they are required to wear face masks during COVID-19 pandemic.

Can be used as a stash buster project, but would recommend using dishcloth cotton or cotton/acrylic yarn so that Ear Mates are hypo-allergenic and washable, and will not over-stretch with continued use.

Please note that this pattern has not been test-knitted by anyone other than myself and all suggestions/corrections are welcome!

NOTE:
All funds raised from the sale of this item will be donated to the GreyBruce Health Unit for the purchase of PPE to help keep our Frontline Workers safe!

PROMOTION:
If you’d like this pattern for FREE, use coupon code “Caremongering” until April 18, 2020

Can be used as a stash buster project, but would recommend using dishcloth cotton or cotton/acrylic yarn so that Ear Mates are hypo-allergenic  and washable, and will not over-stretch with continued use.

Please note that this pattern has not been test-knitted by anyone other than myself and all suggestions/corrections are welcome!

users.about_me:
I was taught to knit by a friend whilst recovering from cervical cancer in 2013 ... she said knitting would give me something positive to focus on during times of difficulty.  She was right and it helped get me through some pretty dark, painful days.  My mantra was, "one more stitch ... just one more stitch".  Knitting became my solace, like a new way to breathe.

My first project was a boring scarf and a pretty sad looking toque.  I quickly grew tired of knitting scarves, toques, shawls and blankets, and yearned to create things "less square" and more organic.  So, I began to challenge myself (through self-teaching) to learn cabling, short-row swing knitting (Strickrauschen) and a somewhat bastardised version of intarsia knitting.

Lots of frogging taught me the inner mechanics of different stitches, so don't ever be afraid of making mistakes.  I've made tons and, I think, they've made me a better knitter.  My next foray is into the world of lace ... wish me luck!!

During the past year, my "pick-up" project (knitting in the car, sitting in the waiting room, etc) has been knitting "pairs of knockers" (a breast prosthesis) for mastectomy survivors.  These are distributed free by Knitted Knockers of Canada ... I'm one of their volunteer Knitting Angels.  So far, I've knit 82 pairs of knockers for women I'll likely never meet ... I plan on knitting hundreds more.

Anyway, it's been an interesting journey so far ... let's see where it takes me, eh?
users.about_me_html:
I was taught to knit by a friend whilst recovering from cervical cancer in 2013 … she said knitting would give me something positive to focus on during times of difficulty. She was right and it helped get me through some pretty dark, painful days. My mantra was, “one more stitch … just one more stitch”. Knitting became my solace, like a new way to breathe.

My first project was a boring scarf and a pretty sad looking toque. I quickly grew tired of knitting scarves, toques, shawls and blankets, and yearned to create things “less square” and more organic. So, I began to challenge myself (through self-teaching) to learn cabling, short-row swing knitting (Strickrauschen) and a somewhat bastardised version of intarsia knitting.

Lots of frogging taught me the inner mechanics of different stitches, so don’t ever be afraid of making mistakes. I’ve made tons and, I think, they’ve made me a better knitter. My next foray is into the world of lace … wish me luck!!

During the past year, my “pick-up” project (knitting in the car, sitting in the waiting room, etc) has been knitting “pairs of knockers” (a breast prosthesis) for mastectomy survivors. These are distributed free by Knitted Knockers of Canada … I’m one of their volunteer Knitting Angels. So far, I’ve knit 82 pairs of knockers for women I’ll likely never meet … I plan on knitting hundreds more.

Anyway, it’s been an interesting journey so far … let’s see where it takes me, eh?

1022414.name: Ear saver with ponytail hole
1022414.notes_html:
This is an adjustable pattern that is mainly fitted towards women or men with long hair in the medical field or sanitation field who are wearing masks a lot and need some relief for their ears. The two buttons helps to go from shorter to longer sizes.

This pattern is illustrated with full color pictures of all the steps. There are explanations for everything being done in detail.
1022414.notes:

This pattern is illustrated with full color pictures of all the steps. There are explanations for everything being done in detail.

packs.yarn_name: Hobby Lobby I Love This Cotton!

users.about_me: Crochet has been a lifelong passion, along with many other hobbies. I never thought about writing my own patterns until about a year ago. I never realized the time and dedication it took to write up one pattern. I never wanted to pay for patterns myself until I went through the design process. Some projects can have 55-100 hours put into it before even getting your work on the computer. I now have an appreciation that I never had before.  I now support fellow crochet designers in buying patterns along with enjoying all the free patterns out there as well. I will be listing free and paid patterns that I hope you all enjoy.
users.about_me_html: Crochet has been a lifelong passion, along with many other hobbies. I never thought about writing my own patterns until about a year ago. I never realized the time and dedication it took to write up one pattern. I never wanted to pay for patterns myself until I went through the design process. Some projects can have 55-100 hours put into it before even getting your work on the computer. I now have an appreciation that I never had before. I now support fellow crochet designers in buying patterns along with enjoying all the free patterns out there as well. I will be listing free and paid patterns that I hope you all enjoy.

1022415.name: Save the Ears Mask Straps
1022415.notes_html:
This is a pattern for a short headband/strap designed to relieve the pressure/irritation caused by medical masks and facial coverings. There are 2 versions of the strap included in the download - 1 knit vertically, and 1 knit horizontally.

It’s placed at the back of the head at or just below ear level, and the elastics on either side of the mask are secured to the buttons on the headband.

The length and width can be easily adjusted by the number of stitches cast on and the number of rows knit.

Please consider knitting some to donate to first responders and healthcare professionals.

The length and width can be easily adjusted by the number of stitches cast on and the number of rows knit.

Please consider knitting some to donate to first responders and healthcare professionals.

1022512.name: Head Band for Heroes
1022512.notes_html:
Head band for Heroes - to wear with PPE masks

These head bands have removable and adjustable buttons for different sizes. They must be made from 100% high temperature washable cotton with high temperature washable buttons.

You can also remove the buttons when you want to wear the head band on it’s own.

MATERIALS
4 ply 100% cotton (use up any scraps you have) and a elastic pony tail hair band or you can chain ties at each end of the hair band
3.5 crochet hook
80 chain equals 39cm
1022512.notes:

You can also remove the buttons when you want to wear the head band on it's own.

1022659.name: Face mask adapter with pony tail slit

1022660.name: Ear saver
1022660.notes_html: This is an adjustable ear saver pattern. The finished product measures 7.5 inches long. I like using the 100% cotton, I love this cotton, it is soft and a great choice. However I have used crafters secret cotton and peaches and cream cotton, they all work well, I love this cotton is just softer. 1 skein will make several of these. I have seen a lot of these that are small and do not work well with the males head, these are longer and will work well with thick hair or a males hair. Plus like I said it’s adjustable. :) Enjoy!

packs.yarn_name: Hobby Lobby I Love This Cotton!

users.about_me: Crochet has been a lifelong passion, along with many other hobbies. I never thought about writing my own patterns until about a year ago. I never realized the time and dedication it took to write up one pattern. I never wanted to pay for patterns myself until I went through the design process. Some projects can have 55-100 hours put into it before even getting your work on the computer. I now have an appreciation that I never had before.  I now support fellow crochet designers in buying patterns along with enjoying all the free patterns out there as well. I will be listing free and paid patterns that I hope you all enjoy.

1022668.name: Stretchy Ear Protector for Face Mask
1022668.notes_html:
Stretchy Ear Protector Strap for Face Mask
Wear this Stretchy ear protector and feel comfortable with your face mask. Health care providers are getting struggling with wounds behind their ears from the constant mask usage. The main features of this stretchy protector are to eliminate uncomfortable tight strings around ears and loose masks that won’t fit. It can be made in any size you want, You can make large amount and donate also.
This pattern is quick, easy and designed espicially for absolute beginners that have experience with the 2 basic stitches, chain and slip stitch. By buying this pattern you support me a lot so thank you very much from heart.
I hope you stay safe & healthy.
IMPORTANT!!!
You’re paying for the digital file only (instantly downloadable as a PDF) and won’t be shipped anything.
The PDF file of the pattern will be available for instant download once payment is confirmed. If you have any questions about the pattern or the download process, please send us a message.
This item can not be sell online, publish in any social media or site, the only requirement is to add in the item description the proper credits for my design.
Due to this product being available for instant download, no refunds are available. Without exception.

I hope you enjoy it and happy crocheting!

users.about_me: I am a crazy crocheter, I've been crocheting for more than 30 years, I like crochet motifs like flowers, leaves and mini laces, I start designing patterns last few years, hope you'll like them, happy crocheting :)
